Gingrich Now Says He Was 'Wrong' to Support Individual Mandate
This article is more than 9 years old.
Well, it was only a matter of time: Newt Gingrich has a new position on
the individual mandate requiring every American to purchase health
insurance. In a statement filmed by CBS News, Gingrich says he was “wrong”
to support the mandate. Gingrich had defended the mandate as recently as
seven months ago, so it will be interesting to learn more about his
journey to Damascus. Some might suspect that it is a conversion of
“I’ve said in the debates, yes, I used to be for mandates. I was wrong,”
Gingrich said today in the video filmed by CBS. “Why doesn’t Mitt admit
it? He’s still for the mandate in Massachusetts.  It doesn’t work, it’s
going to bankrupt the state. The difference between Romney and me is, we
both used to have the wrong idea. I’m willing to say it was the wrong
idea, he’s not.  And I think it’s funny that they want to attack me for
admitting that I was wrong, but they won’t admit that he’s now wrong to
think he’s still right when he’s wrong.”
However, Gingrich has had several explanations of his position on the
individual mandate. In an October debate, Gingrich claimed he only
supported a mandate as a tactical maneuver “against Hillarycare” in 1993,
implying that he has opposed mandates since. However, in a May 2011
appearance on “Meet the Press,” Gingrich said that “I’ve said consistently
that we ought to have some requirement that you either have health
insurance, or you post a bond, or in some way you indicate you’re going to
Indeed, what Gingrich prescribed seven months ago is more onerous than
Obamacare’s individual mandate, which proffers weak and unenforceable
penalties for those who fail to buy health insurance. When David Gregory
asked Gingrich, “But [your plan] is the individual mandate, is it not?”
Gingrich conceded, “It’s a variation on it.” Gregory pressed, “So you
won’t use that issue against Mitt Romney?” Gingrich replied, “No.”
What does Gingrich have in mind when he suggests that people should have
to post a bond if they don’t buy health insurance? A 2008 video unearthed
by Andrew Kaczynski shows that Gingrich favored requiring individuals to
post a bond of $100,000 or $150,000—far more than the $750 fine in
Obamacare’s mandate—if people choose the “immoral” path of foregoing
The third thing I think you have to do, which is for a conservative is a
little controversial, is, I think you’ve got to require everybody to
either have insurance or to post a bond…The fastest growing section of
the uninsured is people [with] over $75,000 income, who are making a
calculated gamble that if they get sick, you’ll take care of them. And I
If you’re well off…the truth is we’re not going to let you die. I
understand the libertarian argument that says “Well, if somebody really
would rather run the risk of dying…” Sure. That’s not going to happen.
What’s going to happen is you’re not going to take care of yourself,
you’re going to be in a motorcycle accident or a car wreck or you’re
going to have a stroke, we’re going to go to extraordinary measures to
take care of you, you’re going to turn out to have no insurance.
And then, given your attitude, you’re going to try to avoid paying it,
which is the other thing I find amazing.  You know, there are people out
there who routinely pay their credit cards because they think it’s their
duty. Then they get to health and they think for some reason, “Why do I
have to pay for health?”  And it makes me wonder, it’s part of what’s
gotten to be wrong with the social contract the last 15 years.
So we think you have to require everybody—the one loophole I’ll give
them is, if they don’t want to buy any insurance, post a bond. We can
figure out the value of the bond, but probably if you posted $100,000,
$150,000 bond, you wouldn’t have to buy insurance because you’d then
have a pool of money who’s available.  Most people would discover pretty
rapidly that that was irrational, and they’d buy insurance.  So that
takes care of, I think, literally, about one-fourth of the uninsured.
And, of course, Gingrich’s latest statement comes on the heels of
revelations that in 2006, he “agreed strongly” with Romneycare, describing
it as an “exciting development” with “tremendous potential to effect major
change in the American health system.”
If Mitt Romney had had this many positions on the individual mandate, he’d
be rightly skewered by conservatives as an inveterate flip-flopper.
Gingrich should be held to the same standard.
